thoughts: French “a” is one of the simplest vowels for English speakers because it is very similar to the /a/ they already know in words like “spa.” The main warning is to keep it short and pure—never let it glide toward a second vowel the way many Americans say the first part of “cat.”
description: A short, pure open vowel. Drop your jaw, keep the tongue low and toward the front, and let the sound out quickly—much like the “a” in British-style “bath” or the first half of “father,” but without any following glide (“uh” or “y”).

thoughts: French “b” is almost always the same voiced bilabial stop English speakers already use in words like “bat.” The only quirks: in clusters such as “bs/pt” it may de-voice and sound closer to a soft “p” (obstacle → [ɔp.stakl]), and in a handful of old spellings it can be silent (plomb). These exceptions are rare, so learners mainly pronounce it exactly as the English /b/.
description: Pronounce it by bringing both lips together and voicing, just like the English “b” in “boy.” Keep it short and crisp—French doesn’t add a puff of air (no noticeable ‘h’ burst) the way some English accents do.

thoughts: French “c” is either a hard [k] or a soft [s]. Both sounds already exist in English, so the only real challenge is remembering when French switches between them.
description: Hard [k] before a, o, u, or another consonant (like the k in “cat”). Soft [s] before e, i, y or when written with a cedilla (ç), just like the s-sound in “city.” No puff of air is added, and the tongue stays a bit farther forward than a hard English k.

thoughts: English already has the /d/ sound, so learners just need to be aware that French places the tongue a bit farther forward (against the upper teeth) and never adds the little puff of air (aspiration) some English speakers give after an initial D.
description: French “d” is a single, voiced stop like English d in “dog,” but the tongue touches the back of the upper front teeth (slightly more forward than in English) and there is no noticeable burst of air. Hold the vocal-cord voicing firmly and release cleanly.

thoughts: The plain, un-accented French letter “e” is one of the easiest French vowels for English speakers because both of its common values (/ə/ and /ɛ/) already exist in English. The only trap is not turning the closed version into an English diphthong.
description: Plain “e” has two main values. 1) Schwa /ə/: a quick, weak “uh” like the a in “sofa” – usually in short little words or the last syllable (le, de). 2) Open /ɛ/: like the e in “bet,” but hold it steady without sliding toward “y” – happens in stressed or closed syllables (merci, belle). It is never the long English “ee” or the diphthong “ay.”

thoughts: French “f” is identical to the English unvoiced “f” in “fun.” No new mouth position is needed, so learners mainly just have to remember that, unlike in some English words (e.g., “half”), the French final –f is almost always pronounced. Very occasionally, in formal liaison, a final ‑f can soften to a /v/ sound (neuf heures → /nœ‿v‿œʁ/), but in ordinary isolated words it stays /f/.
description: Same sound as English “f” in “fun.” Lower lip touches upper teeth; let air hiss out without using the vocal cords.

thoughts: English already has both a hard /g/ as in “go” and a soft /ʒ/ sound as in “mirage,” so French uses won’t feel completely alien; the main job is learning when each one appears.
description:
In French, “g” has two main values:
• Hard g /g/ – like English “go.” It appears before a, o, u or another consonant (gâteau, golf, grenouille’s 2nd g ‘‐gl‐’).
• Soft g /ʒ/ – like the s in English “vision.” It shows up before e, i, y or at the word-end “-ge” (genre, neige).  
A silent u often follows g (as “gu”) to keep the hard sound before e/i/y (guitare, guerre).  When you see “gn” the sound changes to the “ny” of “canyon,” but that is its own pattern.  Most English speakers already use both /g/ and /ʒ/; just memorize the French spelling rules.

thoughts: English speakers expect to breathe out /h/, but in French the letter is always silent; the only challenge is remembering when liaison/elision are allowed (h muet) or blocked (h aspiré).
description:
In French the written “h” is NEVER voiced like the English /h/.  There are two kinds:
• h muet ("mute h") – completely silent and behaves as if the word started with a vowel: l’hôtel, j’habite.
• h aspiré ("aspirated h") – still silent, but it blocks liaison and elision: le héros (not l’héros), les héros (the final ‑s is not linked).
So: don’t pronounce the sound; just remember whether to link the preceding word.

thoughts: French “i” is simply the pure high front vowel [i]. English speakers know a close version in the word “machine,” but English often turns it into a slight diphthong (“ee-uh”). The main thing is to keep it short and steady, without gliding.
description: Like the “ee” in English “machine,” but shorter and without any trailing “y” sound. Lips stay spread, tongue high and forward; hold the single, pure vowel and stop—no glide.

thoughts: French “j” is always the single sound /ʒ/ (like the s in “meaSure”). English speakers know the sound, but they usually see it spelled “s”, “si”, or “g” (vision, genre). Seeing the letter j produce /ʒ/ instead of /dʒ/ (“jam”) is the main surprise.
description: Pronounce it as a soft, buzzing shhh: start to say English “zh” (the middle of “meaSure”, “viSion”) with your vocal cords vibrating, tongue just behind the upper teeth-ridge, lips relaxed (not rounded like English “sh”). Never add a d-sound in front of it.

thoughts: French /k/ is essentially the same consonant English speakers already use, so it should feel familiar. The only real novelty is that French pronounces it without the little burst of air (aspiration) that often follows an English ‘k’. Because the letter k is uncommon in native French words but common in modern borrowings, learners will meet it mostly in international or English-derived vocabulary.
description: Same hard “k” sound as in English “skill,” but produced with almost no puff of air. Back of the tongue touches the soft palate; let the sound release cleanly without aspiration.

thoughts: French “l” is basically the same light /l/ English speakers use at the start of a word like “leaf.” The only hiccup is that French never has the velarized “dark-l” many English speakers make at the ends of syllables (as in “ball”), so learners just need to keep it light everywhere.
description: A clear, light “l” made by touching the tongue tip to the alveolar ridge (just behind the upper teeth) and letting air flow along the sides. It sounds like the first l in English “light,” even at the ends of words. Avoid the thicker ‘dark l’ you may use in English words like “ball.”

thoughts: English already has the /m/ sound; French uses the same lip-closed nasal consonant with no extra puff of air. The only caution is to keep the lips lightly closed and immediately move to the next vowel—don’t add a lingering humming or an extra vowel as some English speakers do at word-ends.
description: Exactly the same as English “m” in “map.” Close the lips, let the sound resonate through the nose, then release straight into the next vowel or consonant. No aspiration or added vowel needed.

thoughts: English speakers already know the basic /n/ sound. The only surprise is that a final “n” (or an “n” before certain consonants) often isn’t pronounced in French; instead it nasalises the preceding vowel. That spelling-to-sound rule, not the consonant itself, is where confusion can arise.
description: The French letter “n” is usually the same alveolar nasal you say in English "no" or "ten." Tongue touches the ridge just behind the upper teeth and air passes through the nose. However, when a single “n” follows a vowel and is not immediately followed by another vowel or another ‘n’, it normally disappears and simply makes the vowel nasal (e.g. bon ➜ /bɔ̃/). Double “nn” or an “n” between vowels is pronounced like regular /n/.

thoughts: The single letter “o” in French covers two main vowel qualities: a closed, pure /o/ and a slightly more open /ɔ/.  Both are rounded back vowels that exist in English, but English speakers usually add a little glide (“ow” sound) after /o/.  So the biggest challenge is keeping the French vowel short and steady, without letting it diphthong-ize.  Because the mouth shape and tongue position are familiar, most learners can pick it up quickly once they remember to drop the glide.
description: French “o” is pronounced either as a closed, rounded back vowel /o/ (similar to the first part of English “go” but with NO trailing ‘w’) or as a more open /ɔ/ (like many Americans’ vowel in “thought”).  Hold the lips rounded, keep the sound short and pure—no glide.

thoughts: French P is almost identical to English P; only difference is that it’s usually produced with little to no puff of air (unaspirated). Final written P can be silent, so learners should notice spelling-to-sound quirks.
description: Same voiceless ‘p’ as in English (put, spin) but without the strong burst of air you hear in English when P starts a stressed syllable. Keep the lips together, release quickly and lightly. At the end of some words the written “p” is silent (e.g. coup), unless a linking consonant-sound (liaison) brings it back before a vowel in the next word.

thoughts: French q is almost always written as qu and is simply the hard /k/ sound. The main trap for English speakers is to avoid adding the little “w” glide they say in English words like “quick.” Just make a clean, single k-sound.
description: Pronounce it exactly like the English hard “k.” Most of the time it appears as qu before any vowel (quand, qui, boutique, etc.). Unlike English, there is NO /kw/ glide—just /k/. When q ends a word (coq, cinq) it is still the /k/ sound.

thoughts: French “r” is the famous guttural sound made in the back of the throat rather than with the tip of the tongue like the English R. It is produced by slightly constricting the throat so the airflow causes a light friction at the uvula. Because it does not exist in mainstream English accents, learners often substitute an English R or an H-like sound.
description: A voiced uvular fricative or approximant made in the very back of the mouth (near the uvula). Think of a soft gargling sound or the light throat clearing in the English interjection “ugh,” but voiced and smoother. Lips stay relaxed; tongue tip stays down while the back of the tongue rises toward the uvula.

thoughts: French “s” looks familiar but behaves in three different ways English speakers must notice: it can sound like the clear hiss /s/, the voiced /z/, or be silent. The sounds themselves are easy; remembering when each happens takes a bit of attention.
description:
1) /s/ – crisp hiss, like English “snake.” Written as “s” at the start of a word, after a consonant, or doubled as “ss.”
2) /z/ – voiced, like the “z” in English “zip.” Happens when a single “s” sits between two vowels.
3) Silent – final “s” in many words (especially plural articles or proper names) disappears; the word just ends in the preceding vowel or consonant.

thoughts: French “t” is mostly the same voiceless stop English speakers know, but it is made with the tongue touching the upper teeth (dental) instead of the ridge behind them (alveolar).  English speakers rarely notice the difference, so production is easy.  The real challenge is knowing when the written “t” disappears (usually at the end of a word) or when it merges into the /sj/ sound in “-tion.”
description: Normally a crisp, un-aspirated /t/ made with the tongue against the upper teeth.  Final “-t” is usually silent unless followed by a liaison (petit ami).  In the spelling “-tion,” the “t” is not pronounced separately; the whole ending sounds like “see-on” (/sjɔ̃/).

thoughts: French “u” is the single-letter spelling for the vowel /y/ – a front, rounded sound that does not exist in standard English. Learners must master lip rounding while keeping the tongue forward as for the English “ee.”
description: Pronounce it like the English long “ee” (as in “see”) BUT with your lips rounded as for the English “oo.” Tongue stays high and forward, lips stay rounded the whole time. Do not let it glide to a second vowel.

thoughts: French “v” is basically the same voiced labiodental fricative English speakers already say in words like “very.” Most learners will recognise and produce it automatically.
description: A voiced labio-dental fricative: lightly place your upper front teeth on the bottom lip and let the voice vibrate. It sounds just like the English “v” in “van.” Unlike in some English accents, it always stays voiced, even at the end of a word.

thoughts: French “w” only shows up in loan-words, so English speakers have seen the letter before but may be surprised that it flips between an English-style /w/ glide and a /v/ sound. The main challenge is remembering that many everyday French words with “w” (wagon, Warwick, watt, etc.) use the /v/ value, while others (week-end, wifi, kiwi) keep the English-like /w/. Context or memorisation is the only reliable guide.
description:
In French loan-words the letter “w” is pronounced in two main ways:
• /w/ – same glide as English “w” in “we.” Mouth rounds quickly as you move from the lips-rounded /u/ position to the following vowel.
• /v/ – voiced “v” sound as in English “vet.” Upper teeth touch lower lip and vibrate.
There is no rule to predict which you’ll meet; you simply learn word by word.

thoughts: The letter “x” is visually the same as in English, so learners already recognize it, but its French pronunciations vary: /ks/, /gz/, /s/, or silent, which can surprise them.
description: In French, “x” is usually pronounced like the /ks/ in English “rocks.” At the start of many words it softens to /gz/ (similar to the middle of English “eggs-act”). At the end of some numbers it is /s/ (like English “hiss”), while in many other final positions it is completely silent. The mouth positions are familiar; the challenge is remembering when each value applies.

thoughts: French “y” is rarely the English consonant “y” sound; most of the time it is simply the vowel /i/ (like the “ee” in “see”).  English speakers don’t expect the letter y to sound like a plain vowel in the middle of a word, so that can surprise them.  When it comes right before another vowel (ya-, yo-, yu-, etc.) it keeps its familiar consonant glide /j/—much like English “yes, yoga.”  Technically easy to articulate, but spotting when it’s a vowel vs. a glide takes some attention.
description:
In French the letter “y” is pronounced either:
• as the pure vowel /i/ (same mouth position as English “ee” in “see”): lycée /li-se/.
• as the consonant glide /j/ (English “y” in “yes”) when it immediately precedes another vowel: yaourt /ja-urt/.
It never forms the diphthongs heard in English words like “my” or “boy.” Keep the vowel short and tense; don’t add an extra glide unless another vowel follows.

thoughts: French “z” rarely surprises English speakers: it is almost always the same voiced /z/ as in English “zoo.”  The only twist is that a final –z is usually silent unless there’s liaison with the next word.
description: Pronounce it like the English z in “zoo”: vocal-cord vibration, tongue tip on or just behind upper teeth, quick release of air.  Beware of final –z: it is normally silent (chez ≈ “shay”), but it reappears as /z/ when the next word begins with a vowel (chez‿elle, /ʃe.zɛl/).

thoughts: In French, the letter a with a grave accent (à) is not a new sound—it's pronounced exactly like the plain French “a.” The accent only marks spelling or grammatical differences, so the learner just has to produce a short, open “ah” (like the a in “father”). Because the sound exists in English, recognition and production are generally easy; the only real task is remembering the accent in writing.
description: Pronounce it as a short, open “ah,” similar to the vowel in the English word “father” or the first syllable of “spa.” There is no extra length or diphthong—keep it pure and relaxed, mouth open, tongue low.

thoughts: English speakers see â on menus and in place-names, but they rarely know its exact sound. It is basically the long, open back “ah” (French /ɑ/), similar to the vowel in British ‘spa’. In most modern French it is merging with the regular a (/a/), so aiming for a clear, round ‘ah’ is acceptable.
description: Pronounce â as a long, open “ah” produced low in the mouth with the tongue pulled slightly back—think the vowel in British English “spa” or the first ‘a’ in American “father,” but keep the lips relaxed and unrounded. It is a touch longer and darker than the normal French a. Before n or m it nasalises: ân /ɑ̃/.

thoughts: The letter a with a diaeresis is almost never used in everyday French words, but when it shows up (usually in borrowed proper names) it simply tells the reader to pronounce a as its own syllable /a/. This is the same open a sound English speakers say in “spa” or “father,” so the sound itself is easy; the only novelty is the two little dots.
description: ä is pronounced exactly like a plain French a – an open, back-of-the-mouth /a/ similar to the a in English “spa.” The two dots (tréma) just warn you not to merge it with the preceding letter; it stays a separate, fully voiced a.

thoughts: ‘Ç’ (the letter c with a cedilla) simply tells you to pronounce the letter like a soft English “s,” even when it stands in front of the vowels a, o, or u, where a plain French ‘c’ would normally sound like a hard “k.” Because English already has the /s/ sound, the only real novelty for learners is noticing and interpreting the little hook under the letter.
description: Pronounce it exactly like the unvoiced English “s” in “see.” The cedilla just overrides the usual French rule that c+a/o/u = /k/. Keep the tongue close to the front teeth and let air hiss out smoothly—no vocal-cord vibration, no “z” sound.

thoughts: English already has a very close sound (the first part of the vowel in “say”), so the main task is noticing that French keeps the vowel pure and short, without sliding toward a “y” sound. thoughts: English already has the vowel /ɛ/ as in “bet,” so the quality of the French vowel written “è” is familiar; what’s new is simply noticing the grave accent. Most learners only need to remember that “è” is always the open “eh” sound, never the long “ay” of é.
description: Pronounce it like the short “e” in English “bet,” but hold it just a touch longer and keep the tongue forward and relaxed. It is always this open “eh” sound—never the “ay” of French é.

thoughts: French “ê” is almost the same vowel an English speaker says in “bet,” so they have heard it before.  The main challenge is keeping it pure and not gliding toward a diphthong (avoid turning it into “bay-uht”).  Because it is a familiar mouth position the sound is not hard, but the written accent is new.

thoughts: ë is not a new vowel sound for English speakers – it simply forces the letter “e” to be pronounced as its own syllable instead of blending with the vowel before it. The trick is remembering to break the word into two syllables when you see the dots.
description: ë shows a diaeresis (two dots).  It tells you to pronounce the letter “e” separately: usually like the short e in English “bet” [ɛ] or occasionally the closed e of English “ay” without the glide [e].  The key is to make a clear extra syllable right after the preceding vowel (No-ël = no-EL).

thoughts: French î is not its own sound; it simply marks the regular French /i/ vowel, identical to plain i. English speakers already know the basic “ee”-like quality, so the main hurdle is remembering that the circumflex does NOT change the pronunciation.

thoughts: ï is simply the regular French “i” sound, but the two dots (tréma) warn you not to blend it with the vowel before it. English speakers already know the word “naïve,” so the concept is familiar, but they may forget to keep the vowels in separate syllables.
description: Pronounce it like the French “i” (/i/ – similar to the “ee” in English “see”), but be sure it forms its own syllable, separate from the vowel that comes right before it. Say the two vowels one after the other (e.g., na-EEV, a-EE-oh-lee). Keep your tongue high and forward and don’t turn it into the English diphthong “eye.”

thoughts: The letter ô signals a single, pure “closed-o” /o/ vowel, slightly longer and tighter than the first part of English “go,” but without the final glide /ʊ/.  English speakers already know a similar mouth shape from saying the first half of “oh,” so the main challenge is keeping it short and steady—no sliding to a “w” sound.
description: A rounded mid-back vowel /o/.  Start with the jaw slightly open, lips rounded as if beginning to say English “oh,” but freeze there—do not let the tongue or lips move or add a trailing “w.”  Think of the pure Spanish or Italian “o.”

thoughts: French uses the letter “ö” only in a handful of mostly-foreign proper names. It simply marks that the “o” must be pronounced on its own, not blended with the preceding consonant or vowel. For an English speaker it will usually sound like a normal French closed “o” (somewhere between English “go” and “paw”), but you must keep it short and pure, with no glide toward a ‘w’ sound.
description: Pronounce it like the regular French closed “o” (rounded lips, tongue mid-back). The trema (two dots) just tells you not to merge this “o” with the letter before it. Think of saying the “o” in British English “law” but shorter and with tighter, more rounded lips.

thoughts: French “ù” is extremely rare (modern French uses it mainly in the small word “où”). The accent does not change the sound of the vowel; it simply distinguishes spelling. Phonetically, it is the same tight, rounded front vowel [y] spelled “u/û,” a sound English lacks.
description: Pronounced like the regular French “u” [y]—lips rounded as for “oo” in “food” while the tongue stays forward as for “ee” in “see.” English has no exact equivalent, so practice sliding from “ee” to “oo” while keeping the tongue forward.

example_words.cultural_context: Famous in the phrase “Où est la bibliothèque?” taught in beginner French classes

thoughts: The French “û” is almost always the same vowel as plain “u”: the tight, front-rounded vowel /y/ (similar to German “ü”). English has no equivalent, so learners tend to replace it with “oo” /u/ or “ee” /i/. The jaw stays nearly closed like for “ee”, but the lips are rounded as for “oo”. Because the sound doesn’t exist in English, it feels alien and is easy to confuse with the French “ou” /u/. The circumflex itself never changes the sound, it just marks old spelling or distinguishes homographs.
description: Pronounce it as the French /y/: keep the tongue high and forward (as if saying the vowel in “heed”) while rounding the lips (as if starting “who”). Do NOT glide or open the mouth. Length is short and steady.

thoughts: French very rarely writes a tréma on the letter u, but when it does the purpose is to force you to pronounce that u as the front-rounded vowel /y/ instead of letting it disappear into the preceding g or q. English has no true /y/ sound, so learners usually substitute something between the English “ee” of “see” and the “oo” of “too.” They must keep the tongue forward (like for “ee”) while rounding the lips (like for “oo”). Because the spelling is so uncommon, most English speakers have seen this letter only in a handful of proper names or in the reformed spellings of words such as “aigüe.”
description: ü = the French front-rounded high vowel /y/. Say English “ee” but round your lips as though saying “oo,” keeping the tongue high and forward. Do not add a glide or turn it into “you.”

thoughts: Very rare letter; English speakers almost never meet it except on some French place-names (e.g. Aÿ in Champagne). Sound is not exotic – it is the same as an ordinary French “y / i/” or the glide /j/. The trema just signals it must be pronounced as a separate sound from the preceding vowel, so the practical challenge is recognising the letter, not making a new sound.
description:
Pronounced the same as a regular French “y”.
• When it acts as a vowel it is the high-front /i/ sound, close to the English “ee” in “see” but shorter and tenser.
• When it starts a glide it sounds like the English “y” in “yes”.
The two dots (tréma) simply warn you not to merge it with the vowel before it.

thoughts: The ligature œ represents the rounded front vowel /œ/, a sound English doesn’t really use. Learners will likely have seen it in food & art phrases (hors d’œuvres, chef-d’œuvre) but rarely know how to say it. The mouth is shaped as for the English “uh” in “cup” while the lips are rounded as if to whistle. Because the sound and symbol are both unfamiliar, it poses a fair challenge.
description: Usually pronounced like a short, rounded version of the English “uh” in “cup” but with the lips puckered (IPA /œ/). Think of starting to say the vowel in “bird” (British) or “fur,” then round your lips. In a few scholarly/Latin words it can sound more like /e/, but the /œ/ value is by far the most common.

thoughts: French “ai” has two common vowel values. Inside a word it is usually the open “eh” /ɛ/—think of the vowel in English “bet,” but held a touch longer. At the very end of a word (or before a silent final consonant such as –t) it tightens to a closed “ay” /e/, similar to the vowel in English “say” but without sliding-off; keep your tongue steady and don’t add a y-glide.
description: Most often /ɛ/ (open “eh”) inside a word; becomes /e/ (closed, pure “ay”) at the end. Unlike English, it is never a diphthong—mouth stays still.

thoughts: “ei” is not one of the trickier French spellings for an English speaker.  Most of the time it is the open-mid front vowel /ɛ/ (like the “e” in English “bet”).  In the sequence “eil/elle/eille” it glides to /ɛj/ (roughly “eh-y”).  Both sounds exist in English, so the only real task is remembering to keep the French vowel short and pure.
description: Usually pronounced /ɛ/ – the pure “eh” of English “bet.”  Before an “l” it becomes /ɛj/, a quick “eh-y” glide similar to the end of English “hey” but shorter.

thoughts: English speakers meet the French “oi” all the time in words like “croissant” and the interjection “voilà”. The sound is basically /wa/ – a quick English “w” followed by a short, open ‘ah’. The lips start rounded (as if to say “oo”) then immediately open to an “ah”. No real diphthong like the English "boy"; it is shorter and flatter.
description: Pronounced roughly like the start of English “wah!”. Think of saying “w” plus the vowel in “father”: /wa/. Keep it short and do not glide into a long ‘y’ sound as in English “boy.”

thoughts: French “oy” is really just another spelling of the common French sound /wa/.  English speakers know the letters “oy” from words like “boy”, but in French the two letters never make the English diphthong /ɔɪ/.  Instead you start with a quick w-glide (as in English “w” in “water”) and immediately open into a short, bright “ah” (as in “father”).  It is the same sound you already meet in French “oi” (moi, trois).  Because the letters look familiar but are said quite differently, learners often mis-pronounce it as /ɔɪ/.
description: Pronounce it /wa/: a quick English-style “w” followed by the open ‘ah’ sound.  Do NOT say the English “oy” as in “boy.”  Keep it one smooth syllable, lips rounded for the w then relaxing for the a.

thoughts: “ui” in French almost always represents the glide-plus-vowel sequence /ɥi/.  English has nothing exactly like the front-rounded glide /ɥ/, so learners tend to replace it with /wi/ (“wee”).  The real sound is made by rounding the lips as if saying French “u” (/y/ – like a tight English "oo") while the tongue moves quickly toward a high front "ee" position.  So it’s a very fast "ü-ee" merged into one syllable.
description: Pronounce it as one quick syllable /ɥi/: start with tightly rounded lips (as for a French "u"), then glide immediately into an "ee" sound while keeping the lips rounded.  It will resemble English “wee” but with more lip rounding and a narrower mouth.  Don’t split it into two syllables and don’t let the lips un-round too early.

thoughts: English speakers already know the “oo” sound, so the French spelling “ou” feels familiar. The only twist is that French keeps it a pure single vowel /u/, never the diphthong /uw/ many Americans add. When another vowel follows, “ou” may glide into /w/ (e.g., Louis /lwi/), but the mouth still starts in the same rounded position.
description: Most of the time “ou” is the single, tense, rounded vowel /u/, very close to the “oo” in English “food,” but held a bit shorter and without sliding. Before another vowel it often becomes the consonant-like glide /w/, as in “Louis.” Round your lips firmly and keep the tongue high and back; don’t let it drift or add a y-like off-glide.

thoughts: French “eu” has no exact English twin; learners must master lip rounding while keeping the tongue relatively forward. Two main qualities: closed /ø/ (as in “bleu”) and open /œ/ (as in “neuf”). English speakers may have heard it in words like “euro” but still struggle to reproduce it.
description: Round your lips as though saying English “oo,” but keep your tongue in the position for the vowel in “bed.” Sustain the sound—don’t glide. In stressed syllables or before a silent final consonant it is usually the more closed /ø/ (tighter lips); before pronounced consonants it tends to be the more open /œ/ (slightly laxer).

thoughts: French “au” is almost always a single, pure round vowel, not a diphthong like English “ow/au.”  English speakers already see it in several loan-words, but may lengthen it or glide it.  They need to keep it short and keep the lips rounded.
description: Usually pronounced like the pure French close-mid rounded vowel /o/ – similar to the first half of English “oh” but shorter and with steadier lip rounding.  In a few common words before l or r it can be the slightly more open /ɔ/ (like the vowel in British “thought”).  Do not let it glide into a ‘w’ sound.

thoughts: “eau” is one of the first French vowel spellings English speakers bump into (beau, bureau, plateau). The sound itself is essentially the pure French /o/; the only trap is to avoid the English-style diphthong /oʊ/. Because the letters show up in many loan-words, the look and the sound are already fairly familiar.
description: Usually pronounced as a single, steady "oh" sound /o/ – similar to the vowel in English “go,” but without letting it glide toward a /ʊ/ at the end. Keep the lips rounded and hold the vowel steady. (In a few rare grammatical endings it can sound closer to /ø/, but not in the common words English speakers meet.)

thoughts: English speakers occasionally meet “oeu/œu” in food terms like “hors d’œuvres” or literary talk about an artist’s “oeuvre,” so the pattern isn’t totally alien, but the actual vowel quality (a rounded front vowel) does not exist in standard English. There are two main realizations: a tighter, closer [ø] when the syllable is closed or word-final and a slightly more open [œ] before pronounced consonants. Both sound a bit like the vowel in English “sir” or “her,” but you must round your lips as if starting to say “oo.” Because lip-rounding while keeping the tongue forward is new, it feels tricky.
description: Pronounce it as a rounded front vowel. Start with the tongue position for the English ‘uh’ in “her,” then push the tongue slightly forward toward “eh” while rounding the lips. When it ends a word or is followed only by silent letters, it’s usually the tighter [ø] (longer, closer). Before a pronounced consonant (e.g., v, r) it opens slightly to [œ]. Both variants are represented by the single spelling “oeu” or the ligature “œu.”

thoughts: English speakers have seen the letters "oe/œ" in words like "œuvre" or "boeuf", but the actual French vowel it represents (/ø/ or /œ/) does not exist in English. It is a rounded version of the "uh" sound in “cup,” so it tends to be perceived as hard to place. Occasionally, the same spelling in learned/Greek words is read simply /e/, but that is far rarer in everyday vocabulary.
description: Most of the time, “oe” written as the ligature œ (often typed just “oe”) is pronounced like French “eu”: a mid-front, rounded vowel /ø/ or the slightly more open /œ/. Think of saying the English "uh" in “cup” while rounding the lips as if starting to whistle. Much less commonly, in a handful of scholarly words from Greek, “oe” is pronounced /e/ (like é).

thoughts: “an” in French is almost never the two sounds /æ/ + /n/ that English speakers expect. Instead, the two letters fuse into one nasal vowel /ɑ̃/: start with an open "ah" (as in British “posh”), keep the tongue low and back, then let air leak out through the nose while lightly cutting off the /n/. Don’t actually voice an /n/ at the end.
description: French “an” is pronounced as the single nasal vowel /ɑ̃/. It’s like saying “ah” while humming through your nose and not touching the tongue to the roof of the mouth. The lips stay relaxed and the sound is shorter than an English vowel + n combination.

thoughts: English speakers already see “am” in French loan-words like “champagne,” but they may not realise it can be nasal (/ɑ̃/) or an ordinary a-plus-m (/am/). The nasal version is new to them; the oral version feels natural.
description: 1) Most of the time, when “am” is followed by another consonant or ends the word, the vowel becomes the nasal sound /ɑ̃/: lower your jaw as for the ‘a’ in “father,” let the sound resonate in your nose, and do NOT close the lips for an ‘m.’ 2) When “am” is followed by a vowel (amour) or doubled (amm), the nasal effect disappears—you simply say an open ‘a’ plus an audible ‘m,’ much like English “am.”

thoughts: English speakers see “en” in loan-words like “encore” or “ennui”, so they’ve met the spelling, but the French sound is a nasal vowel that doesn’t really exist in English. You let the air flow out through both mouth and nose while your tongue and jaw form something between the English “ah” in ‘father’ and “aw” in ‘law’. It never finishes with an audible N unless another vowel follows.
description: Most of the time “en” is the nasal vowel /ɑ̃/: open your mouth as for the ‘ah’ in “father,” round very slightly like the start of “on,” and let some air escape through your nose—no separate N sound. If another vowel follows (e.g. “en a-”, “en o-”) or if the spelling ends in –enne/–enner, it is pronounced /ɛn/ (like the “en” in English “tenant”).

thoughts: “em” is deceptive for English speakers: most of the time it marks a nasal vowel /ɑ̃/, but when doubled (emm) or followed by another vowel the sound is not nasal and the m is pronounced. Choosing examples the learner already sees in English—empire, femme fatale, crème brûlée—shows the two main outcomes.
description:
In French, “em” has two main values:
1) Nasal /ɑ̃/ – If “em” comes before another consonant (except m or n), the e is pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɑ̃/ (similar to saying “ah” while letting air out of your nose) and the m itself is silent.
2) Regular /ɛm/ or /am/ – If “em” is followed by another m or by a vowel/ending, there is NO nasalization; you just pronounce the e as open “eh” (/ɛ/) or “ah” (/a/) and keep the /m/ consonant, e.g. “femme” /fam/ or “crème” /kʁɛm/.
Tip: For the nasal version, lower your soft palate (like when humming) and avoid closing your lips for an /m/.

thoughts: “on” nearly always marks the nasal vowel /ɔ̃/. English speakers have heard it in phrases like “bon appétit,” but English has no true nasal vowels, so the tongue/jaw position is easy but the nasal airflow is new.
description: Pronounce it as the French nasal vowel /ɔ̃/: start as if saying the English "aw" in "law," then let the sound resonate through your nose while keeping lips slightly rounded; the final “n” is not pronounced. If another vowel follows (e.g., liaison) it may sound like regular “on” (/ɔn/), but the common case is the nasal vowel.

thoughts: “om” is one of French’s nasal-vowel spellings. Most of the time it gives the nasal /ɔ̃/ (roughly the vowel in English “song” said without the final ng), but if another m follows (-omme) or if a vowel follows (-oma-, ‑omi-, etc.) the vowel stays oral and you pronounce an ordinary open “aw/oh” sound plus m (/ɔm/). English has no exact nasal vowel, so learners must avoid letting any audible n or m escape the nose.
description: Usually pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɔ̃/: open “aw” + nasal airflow, no actual m sound. If another m follows (comme) or the next letter is a vowel (domino), pronounce a normal open “aw/oh” plus an audible m (/ɔm/).

thoughts: English has no exact match for the French nasal vowel spelled “un,” so learners must create a brand-new mouth posture. Some may have heard it when people count “un, deux, trois.”
description: In most French words the letters “un” fuse into a single nasal vowel /œ̃/: start with the English “uh” in “sun,” round your lips slightly, then let sound resonate in your nose while the tongue stays mid-high and central. You do NOT finish with an audible N. If another vowel follows (e.g., “une”) or if the N is doubled (“unn”), the N is pronounced and the vowel is no longer nasal.

thoughts: French “um” is tricky because sometimes it represents a nasal vowel (like the sound in “un”) and the final m disappears, while in many Latin-looking words (forum, album) the m is fully pronounced and the vowel is not nasal. English has no nasal vowels, so the first variant feels new; the second variant sounds pretty close to the way an English speaker already says “forum.”
description:
Two main pronunciations:
1) Nasal /œ̃/ – lips relaxed, tongue forward, let air escape through nose, no audible “m.” Closest English approximation is saying “uh” while humming through the nose. Seen in native French words like “parfum,” “humble.”
2) Non-nasal vowel + clear /m/ – much like English “um.” Common in international/Latin words (forum, album, maximum).

description: Most of the time “in” is one single nasal vowel: start with the English “eh” in “bet,” open the mouth a bit wider, drop the jaw slightly, and let the sound resonate through the nose while the tongue stays low and front.  Do not finish with an audible ‘n.’  If another vowel follows (Pinot, inouï), pronounce an ordinary “ee” sound followed by an ‘n.’

thoughts: English speakers already know the letters i and m, but in French “im” sometimes signals the nasal vowel [ɛ̃] (similar to the French “in”). That nasal quality does not exist in English, so learners must remember to drop the final m sound and let the vowel resonate through the nose. When “im” is followed by a vowel (or written “imm-”), it is just the regular oral combination [im], like the English word “team” without the ending t.
description:
Two possibilities: 
1) Before another consonant (except another m) or word-final, “im” spells the nasal vowel [ɛ̃] — roughly like saying the English vowel in “bed” while letting air pass through the nose and with no audible m.
2) Before a vowel or when doubled (imm), it is pronounced normally as [im] — the high front vowel of “machine” plus an audible m.

thoughts: English speakers meet “yn” mostly in Greek-origin words like “synagogue” or “syndrome.” When the n is followed by another consonant or is word-final, the pair spells the nasal vowel /ɛ̃/, the same sound as French “in.” When the n is followed by a vowel, there is NO nasalization: you just say an English-style “ee” /i/ followed by an n. The nasal version is unfamiliar because English has no nasal vowels.
description:
Two cases:
1. y + n + consonant or word-end → nasal vowel /ɛ̃/ (like saying “eh” while letting air escape through the nose; think of the vowel in French “vin”). The n itself is silent.
2. y + n + vowel → /i/ + /n/ (just pronounce “een”).
Tip: For /ɛ̃/, lower your soft palate and try to hum through your nose while saying a short “eh.”

However, when the m is at the very end of the word (or followed by another vowel), the m is actually pronounced, giving a normal “eem” sound /im/.

thoughts: “ion” is visually familiar to English speakers from words like “million” or “station,” but the French sound is very different. thoughts: French “ill” is tricky because it has two main realizations: either a simple clear L sound or a Y-like glide (often written /j/). description: Two common pronunciations: (1) After another vowel, “ill” is usually a single clear L, like the L in English “leaf”—e.g. ville [vil]. (2) After most consonants or at the start of a syllable, it becomes a glide, close to the English Y in “yes,” sometimes preceded by a short EE: billet [bi-yeh], Versailles [ver-sigh]. thoughts: French “ch” almost always sounds like English “sh,” so it feels familiar. A smaller set of scholarly or Greek-based words use a hard “k” sound, which can surprise learners. Remember: unlike English, French never says “ch” as the English “ch” in “church” unless the word is an obvious English import (rare).
description: 1) Most of the time “ch” = /ʃ/, the soft “sh” sound in English “shoe.” Push the tongue slightly forward and let the air flow over the middle of the tongue without voicing. 2) In a handful of learned or Greek-origin words, “ch” = /k/, the hard “k” in English “scare.” There is no puff of aspiration as in English—keep it short and crisp.

thoughts: French “gn” is usually one single consonant sound /ɲ/, like the “ny” in the English word “canyon.”  Most English speakers have heard it in loan-words such as “champagne” or “cognac.”  A smaller set of scholarly or Latin-looking words (e.g., “diagnostic,” “stagnation”) keep the two letters separate, pronounced /g/ + /n/.  So learners must decide case-by-case: common everyday French words squeeze the letters into one nasal “ny,” while more bookish or international words say the two letters distinctly.
description: Main value: one fused sound /ɲ/—tongue against the hard palate, air resonating through the nose, similar to the Spanish “ñ” or the “ny” in “canyon.”  Do NOT add a hard g.  Keep lips relaxed and let the sound come through the nose while the middle of the tongue touches the roof.  Rarer value: in certain Greek/Latin-derived or learned words, pronounce a normal hard “g” followed by an “n” (/gn/).  Dictionaries mark these cases.

thoughts: English speakers already know the spelling “qu,” but in French it is almost always a plain hard K sound, never the usual English KW.  A few learned/Latin words keep the KW cluster.

thoughts: English speakers see “gu” in words like “guitar” or “Gucci,” so the hard-g idea is not new, but they rarely realise that in French the written u can be either silent (just forcing a hard g) or pronounced as a front-rounded glide /ɥ/ or /w/. The silent version is easy; the glided one feels odd because English lacks the front-rounded /ɥ/ sound, so learners tend to drop it or replace it with a plain w.
description:
1) Before the vowels e, i, y the u is silent and the group simply sounds like a hard g, as in English “get.”
2) Before a, o, u (or when final) the u is usually heard as a quick rounded glide /ɥ/ (a tighter, more fronted version of English w) or /w/, so you get something like “gw/gy.” Do NOT separate the sounds like “goo-a”; keep them in one syllable.

thoughts: “gue” is not a new sound for English speakers – it simply indicates the hard /g/ (as in “go”).  In French the extra letter “u” is normally silent; its only job is to keep the G hard in front of the letter E (otherwise G would soften to /ʒ/).  At the end of a word “-gue” is pronounced just /g/, and if the e carries an accent (gué, guérir) you still hear the hard /g/ followed by the normal French é sound.  The physical articulation is exactly the English hard G, but with almost no puff of air.
description: Pronounce a regular hard G /g/ (like the G in “go”).  The letter “u” is silent; the following “e” is either silent (at word-end) or pronounced like a normal French é/è if it has an accent.  The key is to avoid adding an English-style burst of air after the /g/.

• /sk/ – in all other cases (like the SK in “ski”).

thoughts: For English speakers the letter-pair “ce” in French is actually very friendly: just remember that it forces the letter c to be the soft /s/ sound, never the hard /k/. Because English also turns c into /s/ before e (cent, rice), the idea is already familiar.
description: ce makes the letter c soft (/s/). If the e belongs to the next syllable you will hear a quick, relaxed "uh" sound after the /s/ (like the a in “sofa”). If the ce ends a word, the e is usually silent, so you just hear /s/.

thoughts: French “ti” immediately followed by another vowel behaves in two main ways. 1) In many very common words, especially the ‑tion/-tio/-tia/-tie groups, the t softens and the whole cluster is pronounced /sj/ – basically an “s” sound followed by a quick English “y” glide. 2) In other words (often at the very start of a word or in recent loan-words), the t stays a normal /t/ and you just say /ti/ + vowel, close to English “tee-”. thoughts: Final –e–n–t at the end of French words can be puzzling because it is either completely silent (common on verb forms) or sounds like the nasal vowel “an/ah” with no final t. description: At the very end of a word, “ent” is usually: 1) totally silent in most 3rd-person-plural verb forms (ils parlent → /paʁl/). 2) pronounced as the nasal vowel /ɑ̃/ (roughly “ah” while letting air leak through the nose, no final ‘t’) in many nouns/adjectives (comment → /kɔ.mɑ̃/). The letter ‘t’ is only heard when a liaison forces it before a following vowel.

thoughts: Final plain “e” is almost never voiced in modern French.  English speakers must remember that it is usually totally silent, or at most a fleeting, very soft schwa ([ə]) that disappears in normal speech.  Because English almost always pronounces a written vowel, learners tend to add an audible “uh” at the end; the trick is to cut it off or reduce it to nothing.
description: At the very end of a French word, a single, un-accented “e” is normally silent.  If it surfaces at all, it’s a very quick, muffled schwa, like the last sound in the American English word “comma,” but even shorter.  Never pronounce it like the clear English “ee” or “eh.”  Most of the time you simply stop after the preceding consonant.

thoughts: Final –er can behave two different ways: most infinitive-verb spellings drop the R and sound like a pure closed “ay,” but some nouns/adjectives keep the R and use an open “eh” plus the French throaty R. English speakers must remember when the R disappears and when to growl it.
description: At the end of a word, –er is usually pronounced as a pure closed /e/ (similar to the vowel in English “say” but shorter and without the glide), and the final R is silent: parler → “par-lay.”  However, in some shorter words (often two syllables) the R stays, giving an open /ɛ/ plus the French guttural R: hiver → “ee-vair.”  The French R is made in the back of the throat, not with the tongue tip like English.

thoughts: French -ez endings are almost always pronounced as the single vowel /e/, a pure “ay” sound with no English-style diphthong.  The written z is silent unless the word is immediately followed by another word that starts with a vowel sound, in which case the z is linked and pronounced /z/ (liaison).  English speakers know the vowel but may diphthongise it or forget the possible /z/ in liaison.
description: Usually pronounced like the first part of the English word “say” but shorter and steadier (/e/).  The written z is normally silent.  If the next word begins with a vowel, the z is pronounced /z/ and links the two words (e.g. allez‿y /alez‿i/).

thoughts: Final ‑S in French is normally silent, so the key question is whether the preceding E is pronounced. In tiny function words like “les / des / mes” it is pronounced /e/ (close to the English long A in “day,” but held pure—no off-glide). In most other words the whole “es” is silent, it just marks a plural; you hear only the consonant right before it (baguette → baguettes /baˈgɛt/). English speakers already know the long A sound and are used to silent final letters, but they must remember not to turn /e/ into a diphthong and not to add a voiced S.
description:
At the end of a word, “es” behaves in two main ways:
1. In short function words (les, des, mes, ces, ses, tes) it is pronounced /e/ – like the vowel in English “day” but without the y-glide.
2. In most other words it is completely silent; it simply shows the plural, so you only pronounce the consonant that comes right before it (baguette → baguettes /ba-GET/).
The final S itself is always silent.

thoughts: English speakers expect final “x” to sound like /ks/ (as in “box”). In French, that never happens: most of the time the final x is completely silent, and in a handful of short number-words (six, dix) it is pronounced like a soft /s/. During liaison before a following vowel, the sound can become /z/, but that is an advanced point.
description: At the very end of a French word, the letter “x” is usually silent (Bordeaux ➜ “bor-DOH”). In a few short words—mainly numbers such as six, dix—it is pronounced like the English /s/ (“seece”). If the next word begins with a vowel and a liaison is required, that /s/ may blend into a /z/ sound, but when the word stands alone you will only hear silence or /s/, never the English /ks/.

thoughts: English speakers know the /s/ sound very well. The only challenge is realizing that a written final “s” in French is usually silent, but can sometimes be pronounced /s/ (and turns into /z/ in a liaison). The mouth position is exactly the same as the English unvoiced “s” in “see.” The difficulty is therefore remembering when to say it, not how to say it.
description: When an “s” is written at the very end of a French word it is MOST OFTEN silent (Paris ➜ ‘pa-REE’). A few short everyday words keep the clear /s/ sound (bus ➜ ‘büss’). If the next word begins with a vowel, the normally silent “s” can link to it and be voiced /z/ (les‿amis ➜ ‘lay-zah-MEE’), but on its own it is silent. So the sound itself is the same soft, hissing /s/ English uses; the trick is knowing whether to pronounce it at all.

thoughts: English speakers know the /t/ sound well, but French spelling rules often make the final written “t” silent, which can confuse them. The main hurdle is remembering when to drop the sound and when to keep it (usually pronounced in a consonant cluster like –st or in many imported/technical terms, but silent after a lone vowel).
description: When the letter “t” is the very last letter of a French word, it is usually NOT pronounced (ballet → “bal-lay”). However, if that “t” is part of a consonant cluster such as –st or appears in many newer technical/foreign words, it is pronounced as a clear, unaspirated /t/—lighter than the puffier English final /t/. Think of placing the tongue on the ridge behind your teeth and releasing without a burst of air.

thoughts: English speakers know the printed letter “d,” but French treats a final d very differently: it’s usually silent, sometimes turns into a /t/ with liaison, and only occasionally keeps the voiced /d/. Learners must remember “don’t say the d” unless a special case applies.
description: At the end of a French word, the letter d is almost always silent: the word ends abruptly with the preceding vowel or consonant (grahn, not grand). If the next word begins with a vowel and liaison is required, the silent d re-surfaces but as an unvoiced /t/ (grand hôtel ➜ grahn-to-tel). A handful of short words and proper names keep the voiced /d/ you know from English (sud, David). Think of letting the tongue touch just once and cutting the sound off quickly; do NOT add a following vowel like “duh.”

thoughts: English speakers know the /p/ sound, but in French a final written “p” is often completely silent. When it is pronounced, the sound itself is the same unaspirated /p/ that occurs after an “s” in English words like “spin” (little to no puff of air). The main challenge is deciding when to pronounce it at all.
description: At the end of a word, written “p” is USUALLY silent in French (e.g. coup ➜ /ku/). When it is pronounced (mostly in recent English loan-words like stop, pop, etc.) it is a short, crisp, barely-aspirated /p/, produced with less burst of air than English “p” at the start of a word.

thoughts: English speakers know the hard /g/ sound, but they don’t expect the letter to become silent. In French, a final “g” is usually not pronounced; it just affects the preceding vowel (often making it nasal). A few modern or borrowed words keep the audible hard /g/. The main challenge is remembering to drop the sound in most cases.
description: At the very end of a French word, “g” is usually silent. The vowel right before it is pronounced normally or nasalized (e.g., on → ɔ̃). In a handful of short, often borrowed words (zigzag, drag, etc.) the final “g” is pronounced like the hard “g” in English “go.” There is no soft /ʒ/ option at word-end in modern standard French.

thoughts: Final “ps” in French can be tricky because its pronunciation changes by word: sometimes both letters disappear, sometimes only the s remains, and in a few learned words you actually say /ps/. English speakers aren’t used to letters that flip-flop between totally silent and fully pronounced, so remembering which word does what is the main hurdle.
description:
At the very end of a word, “ps” behaves three ways:
1) Most classics of everyday French (temps, corps) drop both letters – nothing at all is heard.
2) In a handful of short words (laps) the p is silent but you keep the final /s/.
3) In learned/Latin-based scientific words (biceps, concepts) you pronounce the full /ps/ cluster, like the ending of English “caps.”
Tip: if the word also exists in English as a technical term, chances are you pronounce /ps/ in French too; otherwise assume silence.

thoughts: Final “c” in French almost always sounds like the English “k,” a sound English speakers already use. The only wrinkle is that some common words drop the sound entirely, so learners mainly have to memorize which words are silent.
description: When a French word ends in “c,” it is usually pronounced like the English “k” in “back” (tongue touches the soft palate, quick release). In a handful of very common words—often after n or m—the final “c” is silent, so the word ends abruptly on the preceding vowel or nasal sound.

thoughts: “eaux” is always pronounced like a single, pure “oh” sound (/o/) in French, the same vowel you hear in the English word “go” but without the trailing glide. Because many English-speakers have encountered names such as “Bordeaux” or the plural “plateaux,” the spelling looks exotic but the sound is straightforward.
description: Always pronounced /o/ – a clear, rounded “oh.” Think of the first half of English “go,” but keep the lips rounded and don’t let it dip toward a “w.”

thoughts: “aux” at the end of a French word is almost always pronounced as a single pure vowel /o/.  The written “x” is silent unless the next word begins with a vowel, in which case it links as a /z/.  English speakers already know several loan-words that end in “-aux,” so the sound is not foreign, but they must remember to keep it a steady French o (not the English diphthong in “go”) and never pronounce an ending consonant.
description: Sounds like a short, pure version of the English long “o” in “go,” but without the glide at the end.  No /ks/ or /z/ is heard unless there is liaison with the following word.
